parts.question_text: Find the values of \(x\) which satisfy both \(4x - 3 < 2x + 5\) and \(x^2 - 5x + 4 > 0\).
parts.solution_text:
First, we solve \(4x - 3 < 2x + 5\):
\(4x - 2x < 5 + 3\)
\(2x < 8\)
\(x < 4\)

Next, we solve \(x^2 - 5x + 4 > 0\):
We can factorise the quadratic as \((x-1)(x-4) > 0\).
This inequality is satisfied when both factors are positive or both factors are negative.

Case 1: Both factors are positive:
\(x - 1 > 0\) and \(x - 4 > 0\)
\(x > 1\) and \(x > 4\)
This gives us \(x > 4\).

Case 2: Both factors are negative:
\(x - 1 < 0\) and \(x - 4 < 0\)
\(x < 1\) and \(x < 4\)
This gives us \(x < 1\).

Combining the two cases, we have \(x < 1\) or \(x > 4\).

Finally, we need to find the values of \(x\) that satisfy both \(x < 4\) and (\(x < 1\) or \(x > 4\)).
The intersection of these two conditions is \(x < 1\).
